message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Swarm navigation of cyborg-insects in unknown obstructed soft terrain
Paper Abstract: Cyborg insects refer to hybrid robots that integrate living insects with miniature electronic controllers to enable robotic-like programmable control. These creatures exhibit advantages over conventional robots in adaption to complex terrain and sustained energy efficiency. Nevertheless, there is a lack of literature on the control of multi-cyborg systems. This research gap is due to the difficulty in coordinating the movements of a cyborg system under the presence of insects' inherent individual variability in their reactions to control input. Regarding this issue, we propose a swarm navigation algorithm and verify it under experiments. This research advances swarm robotics by integrating biological organisms with control theory to develop intelligent autonomous systems for real-world applications.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found for the search query "robot":

## Definition and Overview

A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.(no content)A robot can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

## Types and Applications

Most robots are task-performing machines designed with an emphasis on stark functionality, rather than expressive aesthetics, and can range from humanoids such as Honda's ASIMO and industrial robots, to medical operating robots, patient assist robots, and UAV drones.

## History

The term "robot" was first used in a play published by the Czech Karel Čapek in 1920 called R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots), and according to Čapek, the word was created by his brother Josef from the Czech word robota meaning 'corvée', or in Slovak 'work' or 'labor'.(no content)The first uses of modern robots were in factories as industrial robots, which were fixed machines capable of manufacturing tasks that allowed production with less human work.

Web search results for query: "autonomous systems"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallenberg_AI,_Autonomous_Systems_and_Software_Program"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"List of driverless train systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_driverless_train_systems"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"}]

I've performed a web search for "autonomous systems." Here are the key findings across different domains:

## Internet/Networking
An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

## AI and Agents
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently. More specifically, an autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Decentralized Systems
An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system. A unique feature of the ADS is that there is no central operating system or coordinator. Instead each subsystem manages its own functionality and its coordination with other subsystems.

## Robotics
In the field of robotics, the most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas, depending upon which provides the most reliable data at the time, and can re-map a building autonomously.

## Research
The Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program (WASP), launched in 2015, is Sweden's largest individual research program. The aim of the program is academic basic research in artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, and software.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "navigation algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Navigational algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigational_algorithms"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Navigation mesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_mesh"},{"title":"Dijkstra's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra's_algorithm"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Satellite navigation solution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_navigation_solution"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_problem"},{"title":"Navigation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_function"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of navigation algorithms:

## Overview

Navigation algorithms are software implementations for portable calculators or smartphones as an aid to the art of navigation, describing both algorithms and software for implementing different calculation procedures for navigation.

## Key Types of Navigation Algorithms

**Pathfinding Algorithms:**
Pathfinding is the search by a computer application for the shortest route between two points, serving as a more practical variant on solving mazes, with research based heavily on Dijkstra's algorithm for finding the shortest path on a weighted graph.

**A* Algorithm:**
A* is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.(no content)A* achieves better performance by using heuristics to guide its search.

**Navigation Meshes:**
A navigation mesh is a collection of two-dimensional convex polygons that define which areas of an environment are traversable by agents.(no content)Pathfinding between polygons in the mesh can be done with one of a large number of graph search algorithms, such as A*.

## Applications

Navigation algorithms are used across multiple domains:
- Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.
- Satellite navigation solutions involve GNSS receivers measuring transmitting time of signals emitted from four or more GNSS satellites to obtain position and reception time.
- Advanced navigation algorithms include piloting and astronomical navigation: loxodromia and orthodromia.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about swarm robotics:

## What is Swarm Robotics?

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)The application of swarm principles to robots is called swarm robotics while swarm intelligence refers to the more general set of algorithms.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.

## Key Principles

Swarm robotics takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation. The field is guided by several principles: robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities through systems like radio frequency or infrared, do not exploit centralized control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 of robots capable of independently physically connecting to each other were used to study swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized, allowing scale invariance.

Web search results for query: "cyborg"

Links: [{"title":"Cyborg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg"},{"title":"Cyborg (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg_(film)"},{"title":"Cyborg (DC Comics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg_(DC_Comics)"},{"title":"Cris Cyborg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cris_Cyborg"},{"title":"I'm a Cyborg, But That's OK - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I'm_a_Cyborg,_But_That's_OK"},{"title":"Cyborg 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg_2"},{"title":"A Cyborg Manifesto - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Cyborg_Manifesto"},{"title":"009 Re:Cyborg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/009_Re:Cyborg"},{"title":"Cyborg 009 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg_009"},{"title":"Cyborg art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyborg_art"}]

Here are the search results for "cyborg":

## Definition and Terminology

A cyborg is a being with both organic and biomechatronic body parts. The name is pronounced /ˈsaɪbɔːrɡ/, and it is a portmanteau of cybernetic and organism.(no content)The term was coined in 1960 by Manfred Clynes and Nathan S. Kline.(no content)In contrast to biorobots and androids, the term cyborg applies to a living organism that has undergone restoration of function or enhancements of abilities due to the integration of some artificial component or technology that relies on feedback.

## Real-World Examples

A human with an artificial cardiac pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator would be considered a cyborg, since these devices measure voltage potentials in the body, perform signal processing, and can deliver electrical stimuli, using a synthetic feedback mechanism to keep that person alive.

## Academic and Theoretical Perspectives

In "A Cyborg Manifesto", Donna Haraway rejects the notion of rigid boundaries between humanity and technology, arguing that, as humans depend on more technology over time, humanity and technology have become too interwoven to draw lines between them.

## Arts and Entertainment

The term "cyborg" also appears frequently in popular culture, including:
- A 1989 American martial-arts cyberpunk film directed by Albert Pyun, where Jean-Claude Van Damme stars as Gibson Rickenbacker, a mercenary who battles murderous marauders in a post-apocalyptic future.
- Cyborg (Victor Stone), a superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics, created by writer Marv Wolfman and artist George Pérez, and first appeared in DC Comics Presents #26 (October 1980).
- Cyborg 009, a Japanese science fiction manga created by Shotaro Ishinomori, serialized in many different Japanese magazines.

Web search results for query: "control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

## Control Theory

Here are the key results from searching for control theory:

### Definition and Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

### How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV) and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Applications and Impact

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

### Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Control Theory

Here are the key results from searching for control theory:

### Definition and Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

### How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV) and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Applications and Impact

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

### Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Swarm navigation of cyborg-insects in unknown obstructed soft terrain". Here's what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes a novel swarm navigation algorithm for controlling cyborg insects.

**Triples Extracted (6 total):**

1. **Swarm robotics** (concept, proposes) - The paper advances this field by integrating biological organisms with control theory
2. **Control theory** (concept, uses) - Used to develop the swarm navigation algorithm
3. **Cyborg** (concept, proposes) - Introduces cyborg insects as hybrid bio-robotic systems
4. **Robot** (concept, uses) - Referenced for comparison of advantages
5. **Autonomous agent** (concept, proposes) - Develops autonomous systems through cyborg insects
6. **Robot navigation** (task, proposes) - Addresses the navigation task for multiple cyborg insects

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed - the file is properly formatted with:
- Correct paper type classification
- 6 valid triples with appropriate entity types and relations
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid

The analysis has been saved to `triples_output.json` and passed all validation requirements.
